title: FM Technology Improves Quality of Life
chief_complaint: I have hearing loss, constant ringing in my right ear, and difficulty hearing in both quiet and noise. I also feel dizzy, have trouble remembering things, and find it nearly impossible to concentrate in my college classes.

problem_summary.onset: Began during military service (2008-2011) following multiple blast exposures (IEDs).
problem_summary.course: Persistent symptoms post-discharge; currently affecting academic and social life.
problem_summary.laterality: Right ear worse (hearing/tinnitus); Bilateral functional difficulty.
problem_summary.associated_symptoms: Tinnitus (right), dizziness/imbalance, memory loss, concentration difficulties, sleep problems, PTSD.
problem_summary.functional_impact: Distracted by whispers/reverberation in lecture halls; fatigue and frustration in noisy restaurants/bars; strain on relationship with wife.
problem_summary.goals_motivation: Wants to succeed in college (first-time undergrad) and improve communication with wife and friends.

history.present_illness: Patient is a Marine Corp veteran (OIF/OEF). Reports hearing/memory difficulties began during second tour. Now struggling in college lectures and social settings.
history.otologic_history: History of ~5 blast injuries. Worst incident: IED to right side while on foot, causing disorientation, right ear tinnitus, and headache. Two vehicle IED blasts causing dazed feeling. No hearing protection used.
history.noise_exposure_history: Combat blast exposures; no hearing protection used during deployment.
history.medical_psych_history: Diagnosed with PTSD. Probable mild traumatic brain injury (mTBI).
history.prior_management: None reported prior to this VA appointment.
history.patient_goals: Address hearing loss, tinnitus, and dizziness.

tests.name: Pure-tone audiometry
tests.key_findings: Right ear: Normal 250-3000 Hz, mild-to-moderate SNHL 4000-8000 Hz. Left ear: Normal 250-8000 Hz with slight dip at 6000 Hz.

tests.name: Speech audiometry
tests.key_findings: SRTs in agreement with PTA. Word recognition scores excellent bilaterally.

tests.name: Acoustic reflexes
tests.key_findings: Present at expected levels 500-4000 Hz. No decay at 500 or 1000 Hz.

tests.name: Vestibular Evaluation
tests.key_findings: Left peripheral weakness revealed by rotational chair and calorics. Diagnosed with Left Benign Paroxysmal Positional Vertigo (BPPV).

history.present_illness: Follow-up for functional hearing assessment due to persistent complaints despite near-normal peripheral hearing.
history.otologic_history: Previous vestibular issues (BPPV) effectively treated with canalith repositioning.
history.prior_management: BPPV treated. Tinnitus management offered but declined (patient stated not bothersome enough).
history.patient_goals: Address difficulty understanding speech in noise and classroom settings.

tests.name: Performance Perceptual Test (PPT)
tests.key_findings: Actual speech recognition in noise was poorer than age-appropriate norms. Patient accurately judges his difficulty (low PPDIS).

tests.name: Adaptive Test of Temporal Resolution (ATTR)
tests.key_findings: Gap detection thresholds within normal limits.

tests.name: Staggered Spondaic Word (SSW)
tests.key_findings: Normal binaural separation and interhemispheric transfer.

history.present_illness: Patient returned 1 month later for follow-up to assess outcomes of the treatment plan.
history.prior_management: Patient reported using the Phonak iSense FM system at least 3 hours a day. Only completed 5 of the 20 recommended hours of auditory training (BFP).
history.patient_goals: Evaluate benefit of FM system and auditory training.

tests.name: Performance Perceptual Test (PPT)
tests.key_findings: Revealed an SNR advantage of approximately +14 dB when using the FM system, enabling the patient to overcome the significant SNR loss observed at baseline.

tests.name: Subjective Outcome Questionnaires
tests.key_findings: Self-report measures reflected self-perceived improvement in auditory memory, confidence in auditory tasks, and processing speed. 6 of 26 items on a generic quality of life questionnaire reflected improvements.

overall_audiologic_summary: The patient presents with normal hearing in the left ear and a mild-to-moderate high-frequency sensorineural hearing loss in the right ear, consistent with blast exposure. While standard word recognition in quiet is excellent (100%), functional testing reveals a specific deficit in speech-in-noise performance (PPT) that is poorer than norms. Other central auditory processing skills (temporal resolution, rapid speech, dichotic listening) are intact. Vestibular testing identified left BPPV, which was treated.
counseling_points: Your hearing test shows high-frequency hearing loss in your right ear, likely from the blast exposure, while your left ear is within normal limits.

Although you understand speech well in quiet rooms, our functional testing confirms you have significant difficulty hearing in background noise, which explains your struggles in lecture halls and restaurants.
We recommend a personal FM system (Phonak iSense) to help bring the lecturer's voice directly to your ears, bypassing the noise and echo in the classroom.
We also recommend computerized auditory training (Brain Fitness Program) to help strengthen your brain's ability to process sound.
It is critical to use hearing protection in noisy environments to prevent further damage to your hearing.
notes_for_actor: Portray a young veteran who is motivated to succeed in college but frustrated by concentration issues.
You should express guilt about your wife thinking you are ignoring her when you actually just can't hear/process the speech.
You have a history of PTSD and mTBI; you may appear slightly anxious or intense but are cooperative.
Mention that the ringing in your right ear is constant but you can ignore it; your main focus is the difficulty hearing in class.
